comment.author: 18823412@N05
comment._content: I'm amazed with these images, but how can i know the exact date of the photos? is there any more information around?

comment.author: 83979593@N00
comment._content:
Hi Pablo,  

We only have the lantern slide themselves for date information. If the slides do not have the date, we do not have other documentation that will tell us the exact date. These were collected over a period of time, started by William Goodyear. Our best guess is that these were probably collected by Goodyear, who was the Museum's first Curator of Fine Arts from 1899 to 1923. Some of the slides date from 1893. To complicate things more, some of the slides were commercially produced, which makes the dating even more difficult. This slide appears to be from a company given the "T. H. McAllister, Manufacturing Optician" caption information.

-Angie, Archivist, Brooklyn Museum

comment.author: 42961921@N07
comment._content:
OZYMANDIAS
I met a traveller from an antique land
Who said: Two vast and trunkless legs of stone
Stand in the desert. Near them, on the sand,
Half sunk, a shatter'd visage lies, whose frown
And wrinkled lip, and sneer of cold command
Tell that its sculptor well those passions read
Which yet survive, stamp'd on these lifeless things,
The hand that mocked them and the heart that fed.
And on the pedestal these words appear:
"My name is Ozymandias, king of kings:
Look on my works, ye Mighty, and despair!"
Nothing beside remains. Round the decay
Of that colossal wreck, boundless and bare,
The lone and level sands stretch far away.[1]
